items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels have now peaked on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water but the lake level remains high. The weather forecast is for a drier day and the lake level will continue to fall slowly. Areas still affected are locations around Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected. This message will be updated tomorrow, the 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have now fallen but remain high at the Llanymynech and Maesbrook river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 4pm today the level at the Cae Howel guage was 4.2m and steady. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but falling at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. 
Crew Green peaked at 5.62m yesterday afternoon 31/12/21, Montford peaked at 4.63m this morning, Welshbridge peaked at 2.38m this morning, Buildwas is predicted to peak between 3.4 and 3.5m this evening, Bridgnorth is predicted to peak between 2.6 and 2.7m Sunday morning 02/01/22.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 02/01/22 or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   We do not forecast the situation to deteriorate any further.
We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels have remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. River levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 9am on Sunday 02/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels are continuing to rise slowly on the River Dee. Flooding remains possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington throughout today (01/01/2022). The River Dee is expected to peak at lunchtime today at 8.2m and then begin to gradually drop. Please be aware that Townfield Lane could be cut off. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (2/1/2022), or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the lower River Ray. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight (01/01/22), particularly in the Islip area. 
The forecast is for a dry evening, with showers moving through overnight. Tomorrow morning (02/01/22) is forecast to be predominantly dry with heavier showers expected in the afternoon.  River levels in the Islip area are dropping slowly, but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. River levels upstream of Lower Arncott are now below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Skipton, Hornsea and Mappleton has been issued for tomorrow morning's tide, Sunday 2nd January 2022, between 4.15am and 6.15am. Strong winds and surge are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is North Hornsea promenade. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will stay in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 2nd January, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible through today, 1/1/22. Flooding may affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. River levels may fall slightly, later today, but are expected to remain high. River levels are forecast to rise again overnight in response to a band of rain passing through. Further rainfall is forecast for tomorrow, 2/1/22. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this time. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded, and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow, 2/1/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the River Thame. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight (01/01/22) especially in areas between Stadhampton and Dorchester. 
The forecast is for a dry evening, with showers moving through overnight. Tomorrow morning (02/01/22) is forecast to be predominantly dry with heavier showers expected in the afternoon. River levels between Stadhampton and Dorchester are falling slowly but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels upstream of Thame are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further showers are forecast over the coming days, so we will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but are falling slowly on the Lower Cherwell. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight (01/01/22), especially in Thrupp and Kidlington areas. 
The forecast is for a dry evening, with showers moving through overnight. Tomorrow morning (02/01/22) is forecast to be predominantly dry with heavier showers expected in the afternoon. River levels around Thrupp and Kidlington are dropping slowly but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels on the River Cherwell in the Oxford and Upper Heyford areas are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are high but falling at the Sutton Gault river gauge and steady at Welney Causeway gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault and the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.
This information is correct as of 15:30 on Saturday 1st January. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 2cm of water currently on the road and lower sections of the Welney Causeway have flood water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway.
Some further heavier rainfall is forecast tomorrow, Sunday 2nd January, therefore river levels may remain high or rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but falling at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week.  
This information is correct as of 15:30 on Saturday 1st January. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 2 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Some further heavier bands of rainfall are possible tomorrow, Sunday 2nd January, therefore river levels may remain high or rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to slowly fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, 01/01/2022 and into tomorrow 02/01/2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
Further light rainfall is expected through Sunday and Monday.  We expect river levels to stop falling and show some slight response to the forecast rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Sunday, 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message:
River levels are falling this morning on the River Ure. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: Windermere Lake level has peaked and is now falling slowly but remains high. Locations still affected are Windermere, Newby Bridge, and Backbarrow. The weather forecast is for a drier day and the lake level will continue to fall slowly. Avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses or around the lake, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow, the 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
River levels are now falling steadily on the River Ouse
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade.
Some further rainfall is expected tomorrow, and we may see river levels rise slightly again tomorrow evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have peaked on the River Ouse in York and levels are beginning to fall slowly. We will continue to monitor levels closely, however no further significant rainfall is expected and we expect levels to continue to recede.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: River levels are falling this morning on the River Ure. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels on the River Pont have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast. No further heavy rainfall is forecast today, and river levels are not expected to rise again. There is no longer a threat of flooding at the moment, though standing water and debris may still remain.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 09:00 AM on 02/01/2022 with a forecast level of 1.31m. 
The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the high water time.
Forecasts suggests further Flood Alerts may need to be issued for tides on Sunday Evening and Monday Morning. We will re-issue this alert with further details should forecasts continue to suggest that it is needed.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Our incident response staff have closed relevant flood gates and have been checking defences.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please avoid flooded footpaths in the area.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Welney Causeway river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The A1101 Wash Road at Welney. 
This information is correct as of 15:30 on Saturday 1st January. Lower sections of the causeway at have flood water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to WELNEY CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Some further heavier rainfall is possible tomorrow, Sunday 2nd January, therefore whilst levels may fluctuate, they may remain high or rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. The River Ouse peaked in York this morning, and is now falling. However levels will remain high throughout the day. No further significant rainfall is expected today.

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible, particularly around King and Queens Staith. The River Ouse peaked in York this morning, and is now beginning to fall.  However levels will remain high throughout the day. No further significant rainfall is expected today.

We will continue to monitor levels closely. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Sunday morning's tide at 10:45 on 02/01/2022 is higher than normal, with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.23 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. At 23:15 on 02/01/2022‚ the tide is similar. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 14:00 on 02/01/2022

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for the North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea has been issued for tomorrow morning's tide, Sunday 2nd January 2022, between 3.15am and 6.30am. Strong winds and surge are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will stay in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 2nd January, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall has been issued for tomorrow morning's tide, Sunday 2nd January 2022, between 3.15am and 6.30am. Strong winds and surge are likely to produce overtopping waves and spray along the coast. The particular area at risk is Kilnsea and Spurn. Please be careful along beaches, coastal and estuary footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. Unsettled conditions are expected over the coming days and it is likely this alert will stay in force. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated on Sunday morning, 2nd January, or as the situation changes.
